questions.text: A 2-week old newborn is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination after the initial newborn examination showed asymmetry of the legs. She was born at term to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Pregnancy was complicated by a breech presentation for which she underwent an emergency lower segment transverse cesarean section. The newborn's head circumference is 35 cm (13.7 in). She is at the 60th percentile for length and 75th percentile for weight. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The spine is normal. Abduction of the right hip after cupping the pelvis and flexing the right hip and knee causes a palpable clunk. The feet have no deformities. Ultrasonography of the hip determines the angle between lines along the bone acetabulum and the ilium is 50°. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassure the mother and schedule follow-up appointment in 4 weeks
Immobilize the hips with a spica cast
Obtain an x-ray of the right hip
Perform closed reduction of the right hip
Perform open reduction of the right hip

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In most infants, mild hip instability (e.g., the femoral head is subluxable) resolves spontaneously within the first 6–8 weeks of life, as growth of the femoral head and acetabulum reduces hip laxity. If mild hip instability is detected at neonatal screening, close observation, and repeat examination after 2–6 weeks are appropriate. However, in infants with clinical evidence of hip instability (e.g., the femoral head is dislocatable) and abnormal ultrasound findings, DDH is unlikely to resolve without treatment. These infants are at high risk of developing a functional disability and accelerated osteoarthritis in the course of their lives. Expectant management would therefore not be appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

In the case of DDH, a hip spica cast is indicated only after an open or closed reduction of the femoral head or following a pelvic or femoral osteotomy. Since none of these procedures were performed in this infant, a hip spica cast would not be appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the hip is not useful for assessing the hip joint at birth because the head of the femur is unossified for the first 4 months and cartilaginous structures do not appear on an x-ray. A hip x-ray would be appropriate (instead of an ultrasound) if the child were older than 4 months.

D) INCORRECT:

The clunk heard during the Ortolani maneuver (abduction of a flexed hip) indicates reduction of the dislocated hip. Therefore, further maneuvers to reduce the hip are not needed. In infants with DDH older than 6 months, contractures develop around the hip joint and make hip abduction difficult. Closed reduction of the hip joint under general anesthesia would be indicated in such a scenario.

E) CORRECT:

A harness that keeps the hips abducted to 50° and flexed to 90–100° to achieve concentric reduction of the femoral head is the treatment of choice for DDH in infants who are less than 6 months old. The harness should be worn for at least 23 hours/day for 6–8 weeks. The type of abduction harness (rigid vs. nonrigid harness) used varies by region and institutional protocols.

Nonrigid harnesses (e.g., the Pavlik harness) are the most commonly used orthotic among patients with DDH, although recent evidence suggests rigid harnesses (e.g., von Rosen harness) are associated with better outcomes.

F) INCORRECT:

Open reduction of the dislocated femoral head is the treatment of choice for DDH in patients 12–18 months of age. In individuals > 18 months of age, pelvic and/or femoral osteotomy may also be performed. This patient is 2 weeks old and therefore requires a different step in management.
questions.hint: This newborn has a positive Ortolani sign (the clunk heard and felt on abducting her flexed hip), which suggests developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). The sex of the child (female) and a breech presentation are risk factors for DDH. An alpha angle (angle between lines along the bone acetabulum and the ilium) of less than 60° on ultrasound also indicates DDH.

questions.text: A 3855-g (8-lb 8-oz) newborn is examined shortly after birth. She was delivered at 40 weeks' gestation by cesarean delivery because of breech presentation. Pregnancy was otherwise uncomplicated. Physical examination shows asymmetrical thigh creases. The left leg is shorter than the right leg and positioned in external rotation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head
Traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Avascular necrosis of the femoral head is the pathophysiology underlying Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, which may be unilateral or bilateral. Affected patients generally present with hip pain (occasionally projecting to the knee), limited internal rotation, and an antalgic gait, none of which is seen in this patient (and which would be difficult to assess at this time). Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease typically manifests in children 4–10 years of age and would not be expected in a newborn.
Image Description:

Pelvic x-ray (AP view).

The right femoral epiphysis (blue overlay) is flattened and compressed (arrowheads).
On the left side the femoral head is sclerosed and fragmented (exemplary marked with blue overlay and arrows).

This radiographic appearance is typical of the idiopathic avascular necrosis seen in Legg–Calvé–Perthes disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with a fracture of the femoral neck classically present with a shortened and externally rotated leg (which is seen in this patient). However, femoral neck fractures typically occur in older patients (> 70 years of age) and would not be expected in a newborn.

C) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the hip synovium is seen in patients with transient synovitis (TS). Patients with TS typically present with hip pain and a limp, neither of which is seen in this patient (and which would be difficult to assess at this time). This inflammatory condition, which is usually self-limiting, most often occurs after viral illnesses in children 3–8 years of age and would not be likely in a newborn. Moreover, the patient here has signs of hip instability (i.e., leg length discrepancy, asymmetrical gluteal folds), which are not consistent with TS.

D) CORRECT:

An abnormality in the development of the acetabulum and its relationship to the femoral head is the underlying cause of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). Depending on the affected structures, DDH can cause hip instability (capsular laxity), subluxation of the femoral head, hip dislocation, and/or acetabular dysplasia. The etiology is not yet fully understood, but risk factors include breech presentation, female sex, and a family history of DDH. Most cases of DDH involve the left hip. Physical examination typically shows leg length discrepancy, hip instability, limited or asymmetrical hip abduction, asymmetrical gluteal folds, and a positive Galeazzi sign.

Early detection of DDH is important, as the prognosis worsens with increasing age. Hip ultrasound is the imaging modality of choice in all infants younger than 4 months of age. A harness is the treatment of choice for infants with DDH who are younger than 6 months of age.
Image Description:

Pelvis and hips (AP view) of a 3 month old infant

Hilgenreiner’s line has been drawn horizontally connecting the inferior aspect of the ilium through the triradiate cartilages. The femoral heads should be below this line. The acetabular angle is measured between Hilgenreiner’s line and a line parallel to the acetabular roof.

The acetabular angle (or acetabular index) should be < 28 degrees at birth and should progressively decrease with hip maturation. At 3 months old, the normal acetabular angle is typically reported as in the range of 25 degrees, with a maximum measurement of 30 degrees. The acetabular angle in this patient is >30 degrees.

E) INCORRECT:

Traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle is characteristic of Osgood-Schlatter disease. Osgood-Schlatter disease classically manifests in children 9–14 years of age with anterior knee pain and point tenderness over the tibial tuberosity, which is not reported in this patient. Moreover, this newborn has signs of hip instability (i.e., leg length discrepancy, asymmetrical gluteal folds), which are not consistent with Osgood-Schlatter disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Displacement of the femoral epiphysis is seen in patients with slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE), which can manifest with hip instability and external rotation of the leg. However, SCFE occurs most often in boys with obesity who are 10–16 years of age and is not expected in a newborn.
questions.hint: Further examination of this patient will likely reveal signs of hip instability such as a palpable clunk when the left hip is abducted, flexed, and lifted forward (Ortolani sign) as well as a similar clunk when posterior pressure is applied on the flexed hip (Barlow sign).

questions.text: A 3-month-old girl is brought to the office by her mother for a routine examination. Pregnancy was complicated by fetal macrosomia and the patient was born at term via an uncomplicated cesarean delivery. She is exclusively breastfed. She has received all routine immunizations and takes no medications. She appears well. She is at the 80th percentile for length and 90th percentile for weight. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 148/min, and respirations are 37/min. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The spine appears normal. When the patient is placed in a supine position with the hips and knees flexed and the feet placed flat on the examination table, the left knee is lower than the right knee. The feet show no deformities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the left hip can aid in the diagnosis of DDH and soft tissue complications (e.g., avascular necrosis, iliopsoas tendon compression) related to DDH. However, MRI studies are difficult in newborns without sedation and therefore are not the imaging modality of choice.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with DDH are at risk for developing functional disability and/or osteoarthritis and therefore require treatment as soon as possible. DDH is unlikely to resolve without intervention; this patient with findings suggestive of DDH needs further investigation.

C) INCORRECT:

X-rays of the pelvis (in AP and frog-leg lateral view) are used to diagnose DDH in children > 4–6 months when bone ossification has begun, so it would not be appropriate in this 3-month old child. If ossification has not begun, x-rays are less helpful because unossified cartilage is poorly visible on radiographs.
Image Description:

Pelvis and hips (AP view) of a 3 month old infant

Hilgenreiner’s line has been drawn horizontally connecting the inferior aspect of the ilium through the triradiate cartilages. The femoral heads should be below this line. The acetabular angle is measured between Hilgenreiner’s line and a line parallel to the acetabular roof.

The acetabular angle (or acetabular index) should be < 28 degrees at birth and should progressively decrease with hip maturation. At 3 months old, the normal acetabular angle is typically reported as in the range of 25 degrees, with a maximum measurement of 30 degrees. The acetabular angle in this patient is >30 degrees.

D) CORRECT:

Ultrasound of the hip is the imaging modality of choice in all infants < 4 months of age to confirm the diagnosis of DDH. An alpha angle < 60° combined with physical examination findings consistent with DDH confirms the diagnosis. Once bone ossification has begun (typically 4–6 months of age), x-rays rather than ultrasound can be performed to diagnose DDH. Patients with DDH are at risk for developing functional disability and/or osteoarthritis and therefore require treatment as soon as possible because DDH is unlikely to resolve without intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

X-ray of the knee can aid in the diagnosis of knee pathology. This infant shows no signs of knee pain or injury. The unequal knee height seen in this patient is a result of a hip anomaly, not a knee condition.
questions.hint: Female sex is a risk factor for developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH), which can manifest with unequal knee height when the hips and knees are flexed (Galeazzi sign).

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant presents with a 6-week history of difficulty with hip abduction during diaper changes. The infant was born at 38 weeks via cesarean delivery because of breech presentation. Physical examination shows asymmetrical gluteal folds, limited abduction of the right hip to 45°, and apparent shortening of the right leg when positioned supine with hips and knees flexed. Ortolani and Barlow tests are negative. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Observe and schedule routine follow-up in 3 months
Recommend double diapering and recheck in 2 weeks
Obtain hip radiographs and refer to orthopedics
Recommend hip abduction bracing and recheck in 4 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Instability maneuvers decrease in sensitivity after 3 months of age as contractures develop. Another step in management is more appropriate in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Observation is inappropriate in patients with clinical features that strongly suggest developmental dysplasia of the hip, including limited hip abduction, positive Galeazzi sign, and breech presentation history.

C) INCORRECT:

Double diapering is not an effective treatment for developmental dysplasia of the hip and inappropriately delays necessary imaging and orthopedic referral. This patient has a history of breech presentation and presents with limited hip abduction and leg length discrepancy, which requires immediate evaluation rather than conservative positioning measures.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This 5-month old patient presents with clinical features that strongly suggest developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH): limited hip abduction and positive Galeazzi sign indicating leg length discrepancy. Furthermore, the patient's history of breech presentation is a risk factor for DDH. Hip radiographs are the preferred imaging modality in patients ≥ 4 months of age, and orthopedic referral is indicated regardless of imaging results.

E) INCORRECT:

Hip abduction bracing is used in the treatment of developmental dysplasia of the hip in children < 6 months of age. However, this procedure is typically performed by specialists after diagnostic confirmation.
